name: Phillip Hagar Smith
content:
Phillip Hagar Smith (April 29, 1905; Lexington, Massachusetts – August 29, 1987; Berkeley Heights, New Jersey) was an electrical engineer, who became famous for his invention of the Smith chart. Smith graduated from Tufts College in 1928 with a BS degree in electrical engineering. While working for Bell Telephone Laboratories,[1][irrelevant citation] he invented his eponymous Smith chart[2] (which was also invented independently by Mizuhashi Tosaku[3]).
 When asked why he invented the chart, Smith explained, "From the time I could operate a slide rule, I've been interested in graphical representations of mathematical relationships." In 1969 he published the book Electronic Applications of the Smith Chart: In Waveguide, Circuit, and Component Analysis, a comprehensive work on the subject. He retired from Bell Labs in 1970. He was elected a fellow of the IRE in 1952.
 
 This article about a United States engineer, inventor or industrial designer is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it.

raw:
For other people named Philip Smith, see Philip Smith (disambiguation).
Phillip Hagar Smith (April 29, 1905; Lexington, Massachusetts – August 29, 1987; Berkeley Heights, New Jersey) was an electrical engineer, who became famous for his invention of the Smith chart. Smith graduated from Tufts College in 1928 with a BS degree in electrical engineering. While working for Bell Telephone Laboratories,[1][irrelevant citation] he invented his eponymous Smith chart[2] (which was also invented independently by Mizuhashi Tosaku[3]).
When asked why he invented the chart, Smith explained, "From the time I could operate a slide rule, I've been interested in graphical representations of mathematical relationships." In 1969 he published the book Electronic Applications of the Smith Chart: In Waveguide, Circuit, and Component Analysis, a comprehensive work on the subject. He retired from Bell Labs in 1970. He was elected a fellow of the IRE in 1952.

Notes[edit]


^ Sss-mag.com Biography of Phillip Smith

^ "Phillip H. Smith: Originator of the Smith Chart". Microwave Journal. 1 (1): 44–45. July–August 1958.

^ "Smith Chart". ETHW.org. Retrieved March 30, 2021.


External links[edit]
